transcripts.text: Body camera footage obtained by The Intercept shows a Staten Island police officer apparently planting marijuana in a car during a traffic stop.  The incident comes just a few weeks after a similar one, originally reported by The New York Times, in which the same cop was again caught by his body camera in the apparent act of planting marijuana in a car.
All right, this was in the back seat on the floor, so I might want a cigarette.

In the more recent incident, two officers pulled over passenger Jason Serrano and a friend for a broken tail light.  As the officers approached the car and the driver rolled down the window, the officers claimed the cars smell like weed and ordered both people out of the car.  Serrano was recovering from abdominal surgery after being stabbed.  He lifts a shirt to reveal his wound to one of the officers.  Once out of the car, the officers demand to search Serrano's jacket and he refuses.  As Serrano grows agitated, the officers become more aggressive.  They grab him, push him to the ground and handcuff him.  Serano remains on the ground, handcuffed and invisible pain for the rest of the traffic stop, until an ambulance arrives to take him to the hospital.  The two officers, Kyle Erickson and Elmer Pastran, begin searching the car and Serrano's jacket.  Officer Erickson tells Pastran that they need to find evidence.  Officer Erickson begins searching the car.  He searches the passenger side area first.  When he finds nothing, he can be heard murmuring an expletive.  Ericsson returns to Pastranto asks.  He returns to the passenger side and searches through Serrano's jacket, the cup holder and the central console.  As he continues searching the rest of the car, the driver approaches.  Ericsson looks back at the straw and visibly agitated.  After several minutes searching the car, Ericsson again admits that he hasn't found anything.  15 seconds later, Ericsson returns to the front seat cup holder and sets something down.
It's a little bit weird.  It's a little bit weird.

Erickson continues searching through the center console, where he's already looked.  A minute or so later, he again sounds agitated.  Erickson shakes his head as he continues fiddling through Serrano's jacket, just out of the camera's view.  A couple minutes later, the two officers say they found wheat flakes in Serrano's jacket.  At the end of the search, Erickson turns to have fun.  The officers then fist bump each other.  The few awards exchanged between the two officers during the search are almost identical to those they exchanged during the search just a few weeks earlier.  On that occasion too, the search had ended with Ericsson asking Pastran.  An ambulance finally arrives to pick up Serrano.  He spends the next five days handcuffed in a hospital room, waiting for his abdominal wound to close.  Serrano took a plea deal to avoid jail time and didn't learn of this body cam's footage existence until after he pleaded guilty.  The video, which didn't emerge for nearly two years, underscores the limited information available, not just to the public, but also defendants.  And validates criticism by police accountability advocates, the body cameras are of little use if the evidence they capture remains inaccessible.  The NYPD declined to comment on this incident.  Erickson and Pastron remain on patrol.

There's nothing to say that the video speaks for itself.  I didn't have no marijuana.  I didn't have no meat, I didn't have no drugs.  I wasn't driving, wasn't my car.  Toe light wasn't broke.  I had no reason to.  At all.  Besides harassment.
